addition.tex: \emph{Addition} is a binary operation denoted by a $+$ which gives the \emph{sum} of its operands, called \emph{addends.}

bijectivity.tex: Let $f:X\to Y$ be a function. Then $f$ is \emph{bijective} if and only if $f$ is both injective and surjective.

cartesian-product.tex: For any sets $X$ and $Y,$ the \emph{Cartesian product} of $X$ and $Y$ is the set $$X\times Y \coloneqq \left\{(x,y):x\in X,y\in Y \right\}$$ consisting of all ordered pairs whose first element belongs to $X$ and whose second element belongs to $Y.$ More generally, the \emph{Cartesian product} of any finite list of sets $(X_1,\dots,X_n)$ is $$X_1\times\cdots\times X_n \coloneqq \{(x_1,\dots,x_n):x_i\in X_i\}.$$ We can use exponential notation for repeated products.

demorgans-laws-sets.tex: \emph{De Morgan's Laws} on sets state that \begin{enumerate} \item $(A\cup B)^\complement = A^\complement \cap B^\complement,$ \item $(A\cap B)^\complement = A^\complement \cup B^\complement.$ \end{enumerate}

function-forward-image.tex: If $f:X\to Y$ is any function, then for subsets $A\subset X$ and $B\subset Y,$ the \emph{forward image} (or \emph{direct image image}) \emph{of $A$ under $f$} is $$f[A] := \{f(a)\in Y:a\in A\}.$$

function-homogeneous.tex: A \emph{homogeneous function} is a function of several variables such that, if all its arguments were multiplied by a scalar, then its value is multiplied by some power of this scalar, called the \emph{degree of homogeneity.} That is, if $k$ is an integer and $f$ is a function of $n$ variables then $f$ is homogeneous of degree $k$ if $$f(sx_1,\dots,sx_n)=s^kf(x_1,\dots,x_n)$$ for every $x_1,\dots,x_n$ and $s\neq 0.$

identity-map.tex: For any set $X,$ the \emph{identity map} $\text{id}_X : X\to X$ is defined by the rule $\text{id}_X(x)=x$ for all $x\in X.$

function-inverse-image.tex: If $f:X\to Y$ is any function, then for subsets $A\subset X$ and $B\subset Y,$ the \emph{preimage} (or \emph{inverse image}) \emph{of $B$ under $f$} is $$f^{-1}[B] := \{x\in X:f(x)\in B\}.$$

function-restriction.tex: If $f:X\to Y$ is a function and if $A \subset X,$ the \emph{restriction} of $f$ to $A$ is the function $g:A\to Y$ defined by the rule $g(x)=f(x)$ for all $x\in A.$ The restriction of $f$ to $A$ is denoted $f\restriction_A.$

function-value.tex: If $f$ is a function from $X$ to $Y$ and $x\in X,$ the \emph{value} of $f$ at $x,$ written $f(x),$ is the unique element $y\in Y$ that $f$ associates to $x.$

injectivity.tex: Let $f:X\to Y$ be a function. Then $f$ is \emph{injective} if and only if $\forall x,x'\in X,\ x\neq x' \implies f(x)\neq f(x').$

invertibility.tex: Let $f:X\to Y$ be a function. Then $f$ is \emph{invertible} if and only if $f$ is bijective.

kronecker-delta.tex: The \emph{Kronecker delta} is a function of two variables $i,j:$ $$\delta_{ij} = \begin{cases} 0 & i\neq j, \\ 1 & i=j.\end{cases}$$

multiplication.tex: \emph{Multiplication} is a binary operation denoted by a $\times$ or $\cdot$ which gives the \emph{product} of its operands, called \emph{factors.}

power-set.tex: The \emph{power set} of a set $S$ is the set of all subsets of $S.$

rational-numbers.tex: The \emph{rational numbers} is the set of numbers $\mathbb{Q}$ that can be expressed as a fraction $\frac{p}{q}$ of two integers, a \emph{numerator} $q$ and a non-zero \emph{denominator} $q.$

reals-n.tex: The \emph{real coordinate space} of dimension $n,$ $\mathbb{R}^n,$ is the set of all ordered $n$-tuples of real numbers.

root-2-irrational.tex: There is no rational number whose square is $2.$

set.tex: A \emph{set} is a collection of different mathematical objects. A set itself is an object.

set-complement.tex: Let $U$ denote a set that contains a subset $A.$ The \emph{complement of $A$ with respect to $U$} is the set $$A^\complement = U \setminus A.$$

set-difference.tex: Suppose $A$ and $B$ are sets. The \emph{difference} of $B$ and $A$ is the set $$B \setminus A = \{b \in B : b\not\in A\}.$$

set-disjoint.tex: Two sets are said to be \emph{disjoint} if their intersection is the empty set.

set-empty.tex: The \emph{empty set} (or \emph{null set}) is the unique set that has no members. It is denoted $\emptyset.$

set-intersection.tex: The \emph{intersection} of sets $A$ and $B$ is the set $$A \cap B = \{x : x\in A\ \text{and}\ x\in B\}.$$

set-union.tex: The \emph{union} of sets $A$ and $B$ is the set $$A \cup B = \{x : x\in A\ \text{or}\ x\in B\}.$$

singleton-sets.tex: A \emph{singleton set} (or \emph{unit set}) has exactly one member.

source-and-target.tex: Given a function $f:X\to Y,$ the set $X$ is called the \emph{domain} or \emph{source} of $f,$ and the set $Y$ is called the \emph{codomain} or \emph{target} of $f.$

subset.tex: If $A$ and $B$ are sets, then $A$ is a \emph{subset} of $B,$ or $A\subset B,$ if every element in $A$ is in $B.$

binary-operation.tex: Suppose $S$ is a set. A \emph{binary operation} on $S$ is a function from $S\times S$ to $S.$

associativity.tex: A binary operation $\circ$ on a set $S$ is \emph{associative} if $a\circ(b\circ c)=(a\circ b)\circ c$ for all $a,b,c\in S.$

commutativity.tex: A binary operation $\circ$ on a set $S$ is \emph{commutative} if $a\circ b=b\circ a$ for all $a,b\in S.$

identity.tex: A binary operation $\circ$ on a set $S$ is said to have an \emph{identity} $e$ if $s\circ e=e\circ s=s$ for all $s\in S.$

inverse.tex: Suppose $\circ$ is a binary operation on a set $S$ and there exists a $\circ$-identity $e.$ An element $s\in S$ is said to have an \emph{inverse} $s^{-1}$ if $s\circ s^{-1}=s^{-1}\circ s=e.$

z-nz-set.tex: The \emph{field of integers modulo $n$} is the set $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ of integers $z$ such that $0\leq z < n.$

z-pz-field.tex: The \emph{field of integers modulo $n$} is the a field if and only if $n$ is prime.

ring.tex: A \emph{ring} is a set $R$ with the binary operations addition and multiplication that satisfies the \emph{ring axioms:} \begin{enumerate} \item  Associativity of addition and multiplication \item Commutativity of addition \item Additive and multiplicative identity \item Additive inverse \item Distributivity of multiplication over addition \end{enumerate}

ordered-field.tex: A field is said to be \emph{ordered} provided that there is a subset $P\subset F$ that is closed under addition and multiplication and for which exactly one of following is true for all $f\in F$ (trichotomy): \begin{enumerate} \item $f\in P$ ($f>0$), \item $f = 0,$ \item $-f\in P$ ($f<0$). \end{enumerate}

q-ordered.tex: The set of rational numbers $\mathbb{Q}$ is ordered.

r-ordered.tex: The set of real numbers $\mathbb{R}$ is ordered.

c-ordered.tex: The set of complex numbers $\mathbb{C}$ is not ordered.

n-field.tex: The set of natural numbers $\mathbb{N}$ is not a field.

q-field.tex: The set of rational numbers $\mathbb{Q}$ is a field.

r-field.tex: The set of real numbers $\mathbb{R}$ is a field.

c-field.tex: The set of complex numbers $\mathbb{C}$ is a field.

divides-divisor-divisible-factor-multipl.tex: If $m$ and $n$ are integers, we say that $m$ \emph{divides} $n$ and write $m\mid n$ if there exists an integer $q$ such that $n=mq.$ We also say that, $m$ is a \emph{divisor} of $n$, $n$ is \emph{divisible} by $m,$ $n$ is a \emph{factor} or \emph{multiple} of $m.$

linear-equation.tex: A \emph{linear equation} is an equation of the form $$b = a_1x_1 + a_2x_2 + \cdots + a_nx_n,$$ where $a_1,\ldots,a_n,x_1,\ldots,x_n,b$ are elements of a given field.

system-of-equations.tex: A \emph{system of equations} is a set of equations in the same variables.

system-of-linear-equations.tex: A \emph{system of linear equations} is a system of equations wherein all equations are linear.

equation.tex: An \emph{equation} is a mathematical statement which asserts that two expressions are equal.

expression.tex: An \emph{expression} is a well-formed finite combination of symbols with meaning.

system-of-equations-consistency.tex: A system of equations is said to be \emph{consistent} if it has at least one solution, and it is said to be \emph{inconsistent} if it has no solutions.

system-of-equations-solution.tex: An ordered $n$-tuple of $(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n)$ is said to be a \emph{solution} of a system of equations if it satisfies all equations in the system.

ordered-n-tuple.tex: Suppose $n$ is a natural number. An \emph{ordered $n$-tuple} is an ordered list of $n$ elements.

ordered-n-tuple-equality.tex: Two ordered $n$-tuples are equal if and only if they have the same length and the same elements in the same order.

point.tex: A \emph{point} is an object in $\reals^3$ that has position but not dimensions.
point.author: Euclid, The Elements: Book I

space.tex: \emph{Space} is the universe we live in, taken to be three dimensions and isomorphic to $\reals^3.$
space.author: Euclid, The Elements: Book I

position.tex: \emph{Position} defines where an object is in space.
position.author: Euclid, The Elements: Book I

plane.tex: A \emph{plane} is a surface which lies evenly with the lines on itself.
plane.author: Euclid, The Elements: Book I

curve.tex: A \emph{curve} (Euclid: ``line'') is a set of points in space with length but without width.
curve.author: Euclid, The Elements: Book I

line.tex: A \emph{line} (Euclid: ``straight line'') is a curve which lies evenly with the points on itself.
line.author: Euclid, The Elements: Book I

surface.tex: A \emph{surface} is a set of curves in space with length and width but without thickness.
surface.author: Euclid, The Elements: Book I

prime-numbers.tex: A \emph{prime number} is a natural number greater than $1$ that has no divisors other than $1$ and itself.

composite-numbers.tex: A \emph{composite number} is a natural number with a divisor beside 1 and itself.

sum-of-irrational-and-rational-is-irrati.tex: If $\alpha\in\reals\setminus\rats$ and $q\in\rats,$ then $\alpha+q\in\reals\setminus\rats.$ That is, the sum of an irrational number and a rational number is irrational.

even-number.tex: An \emph{even number} is an integer that is divisible by $2.$ That is, it can be written in the form $2k$ for some integer $k.$

odd-number.tex: An \emph{even number} is an integer that is not divisible by $2.$ That is, it can be written in the form $2k+1$ for some integer $k.$

cube-of-even-iff-even.tex: Suppose $n\in\ints.$ $n^3$ is even if and only if $n$ is even.

a-plus-b-squared-neq-a-squared-plus-b-sq.tex:
Suppose $a,b\ineals.$ Then $a^2+b^2
eq(a+b)^2$ if and only if $a
eq 0$ and $b
eq 0.$

zero-map.tex: For any sets $X$ and $Y,$ \emph{zero map} is the map $Z:X\to Y$ defined by $Z(x)=0_Y$ for all $x\in X.$

scale-map.tex: For any set $X,$ \emph{scale map} is the map $S:X\to X$ defined by $S(x)=kx$ for nonzero $k$ and all $x\in X.$

function-real-valued.tex: A \emph{real-valued function} is a function from a subset of $\reals$ to $\reals.$

polynomial-expression.tex: A \emph{polynomial expression} is an expression consisting of variables and coefficients that only involves the operations of addition and multiplication.

polynomial-function.tex: A \emph{polynomial function} is a function that can be defined by evaluating a polynomial expression.

root-of-a-function.tex: A \emph{root} of a function $f$ is a value $x$ such that $f(x)=0.$

multiplicity-of-the-root.tex: Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial and let $r$ be a root of $f.$ The \emph{multiplicity of the root} is the number of times $r$ appears as a root of $f$—i.e., it is the largest natural $m$ so that we can factor $f(x)=(x-r)^mg(x)$ for some other polynomial $g(x).$
